Award.AbstractNarration: The early universe must have contained tiny initial fluctuations, which later grew by the attractive force of gravity as the universe expanded, to become the structures we observe in the universe today. This proposal aims to empirically examine the properties of these primordial fluctuations, and to refine theoretical predictions about their properties. On the phenomenological side, and building on previous work by the PI, the proposal discusses tests of statistical homogeneity and isotropy. If averages of cosmic density fields are invariant under translations, we speak of statistical homogeneity; if they are additionally invariant under rotations we speak of statistical isotropy. Both are two of the key assumptions that underlie most of our analyses of the origin and growth of structure, so it is crucial to test both empirically. On the theoretical side, the PI proposes to further study the predictions of inflation, the leading explanation for the origin of the primordial perturbations. At the end of inflation, the inflaton field must decay into the hot radiation of the Big Bang, in a process known as reheating. The PI plans to study the survival of non-adiabatic perturbations after inflation, and several aspects related to the quantum nature of the inflaton decay. These studies are important to unveil the details of a process that remains hidden by the resulting thermal equilibrium. Reheating may also have indirect implications on the Gaussianity of the primordial perturbations. Calculations of the degree of primordial non-Gaussianity produced during inflation have neglected the couplings needed for the universe to reheat. The PI intends to include the effects of such couplings, in order to verify whether they can be neglected, and thus confirm one of the key predictions of single-field inflationary models. The broader impacts of this proposal are as follows: As a major component of his efforts in public education, the PI plans to draw from his Hispanic background to promote the diffusion of cosmology among Hispanic minorities in the Syracuse area. In collaboration with the Spanish Action League of Onondaga County he proposes to extend the multi-disciplinary educational program in astronomy and cosmology addressed to Hispanic children that he started in 2007. The program is structured in a series of weekly ninety minute sessions in which children aged six to ten are exposed to basic concepts in astronomy and cosmology. In the coming years, the PI intends to build on the successes of the first year of life of the program, and to correct and address the challenges that have emerged so far.

POR.DRECONTENT:
A quite remarkable property of the gravitational force is that bodies with different masses appear to fall with the same acceleration (in the absence of air resistance). The most famous experiment to illustrate this property  was conducted by astronaut David Scott on the moon surface, by dropping a hammer and a feather at the same time,

http://nssdc.gsfc.nasa.gov/planetary/lunar/apollo_15_feather_drop.html

In the context of the theory of gravitation proposed by Einstein, general relativity, this property of the gravitational force just follows from a transformation of the elements of the theory that  leaves the theory nevertheless unchanged.

But many physicists have wondered Einstein was completely right, and have therefore considered alternative theories to describe the gravitational force. The most widely considered ones were proposed (among other researchers) by Brans and Dicke, and include an additional source of gravitational attraction due to a spinless particle.

The question that this project addressed is whether different bodies still fall with the same acceleration in the theories proposed by Brans and Dicke. Although this turns out to be the case when one ignores the subtle corrections introduced by quantum mechanics, the latter actually cause different bodies to fall with different accelerations, basically because, unlike in general relativity, the  only  transformations that leave  such theories unchanged do not constrain the gravitational force mediated by the additional spinless particle.

 

This project also investigated the tiny initial and random inhomogeneities that, under the attractive force of gravity, grew and developed into the structures we observe in our universe today, including galaxies, stars, planets and even us.  Our current understanding of these initial inhomogeneities assumes that their random properties are the same everywhere, a property known as statistical homogeneity, but this assumption had not been explicitly and rigorously tested before the conclusion of this project. The PI thus developed one of the  first tests of this hitherto unchecked assumption. The test addressed whether the mean of these initial perturbations is constant or spatially varying. The former would follow from statistical homogeneity, whereas the latter would imply its violation.  The test concluded that the mean of the initial homogeneities appears to be constant, further confirming and providing support for our current understanding of the origin of structure in the universe.

 

As illustrated by the discussion above,  the set of transformations that leave  a theory unchanged play a crucial role in modern physics. Einstein's theory of gravity, in the presence of matter such as electrons or protons, has two sets of such transformations: Transformations that relabel the coordinates of spacetime events (known as diffeomorphisms) and transformations that "mix" four arbitrary and mutually orthogonal directions (known as local Lorentz transformations).  The final part of this project investigated the structure of gravitational theories in which diffeomorphisms still leave a theory invariant, but local Lorentz transformations do not. The latter have a very rich array of experimental implications, particularly as far as the generation of the initial seeds of structure previously mentioned is concerned. The PI and his collaborators found for instance that some of the features of those theories could be visible in leftover radiation from the early universe. In particular, measurements of this radiation by missions such as WMAP

http://map.gsfc.nasa.gov/

already put significant constraints on  this class of theories.
